text: this is alex brown 40 design the New
York Times Style magazine lately Soho
has become something of a mini Milan as
the big names in Italian design descend
on the neighborhood opening showrooms
and stores three such companies coffee
which is known for its kitchens and
baths poro which creates tables chairs
and other case goods and living divani
which creates mostly upholstered
furniture like sofas and chairs have
joined forces in a newly opened retail
space on Green Street which looks less
like a showroom than a sophisticated
loft complete with art antiques and a
wall of books while all the furniture is
for sale the idea is less about shopping
and more about experiencing the products
in their natural habitat we met up with
pierre le sony who is the creative
director for all three companies and the
driving force behind this new retail
concept i put together because it's
possible to show this this level of life
you know it's like a way of life it's a
talent way of life they plan to rotate
the furnishings about every six months
changing the layout in the decor of the
showroom we are thinking to offer not a
catalog but to offer a real feeling of a
natural living room and I put all
together some different pieces are they
all from the same season the pieces
they're all new yeah it's all all of
them is new you know all the old stuff
all together looks like a real house
arrium home with plans to open similar
spaces in Los Angeles and Munich the
only component that appears to be
missing from the package is the real
estate broker
